sanskrit:
अद्वेष्टा सर्वभूतानां मैत्रः करुण एव च |
निर्ममो निरहङ्कारः समदुःखसुखः क्षमी ||
transliteration:
adveṣṭā sarva-bhūtānāṁ maitraḥ karuṇa eva ca |
nirmamo nirahaṅkāraḥ sama-duḥkha-sukhaḥ kṣamī ||
translation: One who is not envious but is a kind friend to all living beings, who does not think of 'I' and 'mine', who is free from ego, equal in happiness and distress, and forgiving.
commentary:
This verse begins a series of verses (13-20) where Krishna describes the qualities of His ideal devotee. These characteristics represent the natural manifestations of a heart purified by devotion. The devotee who harbors no hatred (adveṣṭā) toward any being recognizes the divine presence in all creatures. Such a person naturally becomes a friend (maitraḥ) and compassionate (karuṇa) to all, seeing no fundamental difference between themselves and others.

The qualities of being free from possessiveness (nirmamaḥ) and ego (nirahaṅkāraḥ) indicate the devotee's freedom from the false identification with the body and material possessions. When one realizes that everything belongs to the Divine and that the individual self is merely an instrument, the notions of 'mine' and 'I am the doer' naturally dissolve. Equanimity in pleasure and pain (sama-duḥkha-sukhaḥ) and forgiveness (kṣamī) demonstrate the devotee's stability of mind, rooted in the understanding that all experiences are temporary and are opportunities for spiritual growth. These qualities are not artificially cultivated but emerge spontaneously from genuine devotion and self-realization.
speaker: Krishna
